3 Hours into a game should be enough to show if you want to keep playing. As for me, I've had enough. Some people outright can not play as killers, thinking it was due to everyone wanting to be a killer. Google, and the DBD forums told me it's a bug that doesn't allow certain people to get survivor in their lobby, meaning I payed for half a game. 

Killers that did manage to play, and play numerous times have leveled up, and many Killers have a perk that allows them to see all survivors on the map when they hook a survivor, making it extremely frustrating for new players who can't even use the one survival element given to them, stealth.  

Without friends you can't coordinate and for new players, it leaves you deciding, to help out your team mate, whos being camped by the killer or run to a generator. Although the game is neat and many people find it fun. It has a few design elements that I can not stand which I believe ruin the game. Many people will disagree with me, but if you share my mentality, I would suggest playing another game.

When I first made my review in 2018 I gave the game a positive review mainly because I saw the potential that DBD had and was optimistic about the future. 

Sadly in 2022 I can say that all of my optimism has dried up and I lack any confidence that Dead By Daylight will be fixed in any timely or meaningful manner. 

This game is plagued by a multitude of issues that have gone unaddressed for either months or multiple years. 

These issues include but are not limited to:

- Grind that exceeds 2500 hours which increases by hundreds of hours every content drop
- An MMR system that the devs have admitted does not work and the vast majority of the community does not like but the devs persist on forcing it upon the playerbase. 
- A power creep that has reached its worst point and is being made worse every chapter
- A vast majority of perks being locked behind paid DLC or massive grind
- An extremely toxic community with many players unhappy even playing and thus take it out on their fellow players


and that is very much so the short list. There are many other problems and more problems get added frequently with solutions being seldom and far between. 

This game needs to be rebuilt from the ground up and the longer the devs put off systemic changes the more they are shooting themselves in the foot. 

I do hope the game gets better but from the actions and dev commentary from the past year that is something I very much so doubt.

I love the *idea* of this game, which is why I continue to play it, but cannot recommend it for a couple of reasons:
1) Developers have released consistent patches over 5 years, and nearly every patch has introduced major bugs, which are often fixed in subsequent patches, although those often break other parts of the game.
2) Developers who consistently over promise and under deliver.
3) Developers choosing to focus on expanding their product to other consoles without fixing major issues and consistent bugs on PC.
4) A large amount of grinding is required to have fun (explained in further detail below).
5) Developers frequently shed crocodile tears over twitter (and in PR statements) because they cannot handle criticism or being called over non-functioning aspects of their game.
6) The lack of balanced gameplay. There are ways in which survivors can make the game unfun for killer, and ways in which the killer can make the game unfun for survivors.
7) Lack of survivor interactivity--gens are not exciting to progress, and looping--done by effectively running in circles around a pallet--removes the horror aspect of the experience and the need to think quickly about where to move to next. Survivors have very little opportunities to outplay the killer directly; flashlight saves, sabotaging hooks, etc. is typically a less viable strategy than simply repairing gens as quickly as possible.
8) Toxic community that belittles new players and discourages them from learning. Nearly every match includes players who belittle the other side for implementing strategies, perks, add-ons, offerings, etc, which they deem as "unfair".

If you are still interested in the experience, I recommend listening to int3r4ct's commentary to get started in the game:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yTa6Q-lmaTk

One of the few mechanics which survivors can implement that provides a substantial advantage. Understanding how *fast* vaulting works:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-94Ype1nt5g

-Juego divertido m√°s si se juega con amigos.

-Matchmaking se realiza utilizando servidores de BHVR. Una vez que te unes a un lobby, est√°s conectado al host del asesino.

Aunque la conexi√≥n sea P2P con el host del Killer es normal tener una conexi√≥n de entre 90-250 si te encuentras cerca o de entre 250-500 y m√°s si te encuentras lejos de la ubicaci√≥n de quien hostea la partida. En mi opini√≥n no evita que sea jugable, aunque se puede tornar algo frustrantes partidas de conexi√≥n alta.

-Contenido que se va actualizando constantemente, lo vuelve m√°s interesante.

-Y preparate para una gran cantidad de campers y lag switching.

O jogo √© √≥timo, mas depois que colocaram esse neg√≥cio de tempo de espera quando desconecta, ficou uma porcaria, pois at√© quem √© desconectado pelo pr√≥prio servidor porcaria que o jogo fornece acaba sendo afetado tbm, por causa de um servi√ßo de m√° qualidade que oferecem.
